comments:
Biol 102 is a course on the general principles of biology, focusing on the structure and function of animals, with an emphasis on the principles of physiology, development, evolution, ecology, and the diversity of adaptations, according to the course description.

Students in the class found the professor to be very organized and easy to understand.  Students used the words “excellent,” “highly organized,” and “funny” to describe his teaching style. They also rated his exams at an average level of difficulty.  Further evaluations of student performance were simple in-class quizzes given by the professor from time to time.

The major complaint, from only a few students, was that the professor’s lectures were too slow and that the professor lectured straight from the textbook. As a result, many were skipping classes on a regular basis.

Intro to Biology B, offered only in the spring, is an introductory level course taken as a companion with BIOL101 (but can be taken before or after).  A 3-hr lecture, 3-hr lab per-week course, BIOL102 is a prerequisite for the biology major, recommended for students with only one year of high school biology.  This course can be taken to fulfill the Living World Sector in the College of Arts and Sciences, and can work towards fulfilling the pre-health biology lecture/lab requirement.

The course covers the general principles of animal biology.  A typical semester covers animal development, major bodily systems, physiology, evolution and ecology.  The text follows the Campbell & Reece textbook (used also for Intro to Biology A).  In addition to a $150 lab fee, a lab manual and photographic atlas must also be purchased.

Students found that Professor Kemp was easy to understand and able to stimulate their interest.  Students used the words “fantastic,” “great,” and “wonderful” to describe his teaching ability.  One student wrote that Kemp’s “easy-going style makes learning fun.”  Students found his exams to be an average level of difficulty, and several commented on their “fairness.”  As one student commented, Dr. Kemp “does a good job on testing us on what we learned.”

The major complaint, voiced by several students, was that as section 601 was specifically for pre-health students, many felt that Professor Kemp moved too slowly. As a result, many of them had to take the MCATs before having gone over physiology in the class.  Some suggested reordering the syllabus to avoid this in the future.
